org.gearvrf

Class GVRMaterial

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.GVRHybridObject
      • org.gearvrf.GVRMaterial
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Closeable, java.lang.AutoCloseable, GVRShaders<GVRMaterialShaderId>

    public class GVRMaterial
extends GVRHybridObject
implements GVRShaders<GVRMaterialShaderId>
    This is one of the key GVRF classes: it holds shaders with textures. You can have invisible scene objects: these have a location and a set of child objects. This can be useful, to move a set of scene objects as a unit, preserving their relative geometry. Invisible scene objects don't need any render data.

    Visible scene objects must have render data attached. Each GVRRenderData has a GL mesh that defines its geometry, and a GVRMaterial that defines its surface.

    Each GVRMaterial contains two main things:

    • The id of a (stock or custom) shader, which is used to draw the mesh. See GVRMaterial.GVRShaderType and GVRContext.getMaterialShaderManager().
    • Data to pass to the shader. This usually - but not always - means a GVRTexture and can include other named values to pass to the shader.

    The simplest way to create a GVRMaterial is to call the constructor that takes only a GVRContext. Then you just setMainTexture() and you're ready to draw with the default shader, which is called 'unlit' because it simply drapes the texture over the mesh, without any lighting or reflection effects. 

     // for example
 GVRMaterial material = new GVRMaterial(gvrContext);
 material.setMainTexture(texture);

        Returns:
        The main texture

      • setMainTexture

        public void setMainTexture(GVRTexture texture)
        Description copied from interface: GVRShaders
        Bind a different texture to the main_texture shader uniform.

        Note: GVR textures are reference counted. While you can freely change the texture associated with a GVRMaterial or a GVRPostEffect, a sequence like 

         GVRTexture currentTexture = material.getMainTexture();
 material.setMainTexture(otherTexture);
 // ...
 material.setMainTexture(currentTexture);
        may not do what you expect. The setMainTexture(otherTexture) call will decrement the reference count on currentTexture: If the reference count goes to 0, the texture will be released, and the setMainTexture(currentTexture) call will leave the GVRMaterial invisible (or will break the GVRPostEffect). You can prevent this by adding a new reference 
         material.setTexture("any_name_you're_not_otherwise_using", currentTexture);
        before you call setMainTexture(otherTexture).
        Specified by:
        setMainTexture in interface GVRShaders<GVRMaterialShaderId>
        Parameters:
        texture - The GVRTexture to bind.

      • setMainTexture

        public void setMainTexture(java.util.concurrent.Future<GVRTexture> texture)
        Description copied from interface: GVRShaders
        Asynchronously bind a different texture to the main_texture shader uniform. Uses a background thread from the thread pool to wait for the Future.get() method; unless you are loading dozens of textures asynchronously, the extra overhead should be modest compared to the cost of loading a texture.

        Please see the notes on reference counting in the main GVRShaders.setMainTexture(GVRTexture) overload.

        Specified by:
        setMainTexture in interface GVRShaders<GVRMaterialShaderId>
        Parameters:
        texture - A future texture, from one of the the GVRContext.loadFutureTexture(GVRAndroidResource) methods

      • getColor

        public float[] getColor()
        Get the color uniform. By convention, GVRF shaders can use a vec3 uniform named color. With the default 'unlit' shader, this allows you to add an overlay color on top of the texture.
        Returns:
        The current vec3 color as a three-element array

        public void setColor(float r,
                     float g,
                     float b)
        Set the color uniform. By convention, GVRF shaders can use a vec3 uniform named color. With the default 'unlit' shader, this allows you to add an overlay color on top of the texture. Values are between 0.0f and 1.0f, inclusive. .
        Parameters:
        r - Red
        g - Green
        b - Blue

        Parameters:

      • getOpacity

        public float getOpacity()
        Get the opacity. This method returns the opacity uniform. The setOpacity() documentation explains what the opacity uniform does.
        Returns:
        The opacity uniform used to render this material

      • setOpacity

        public void setOpacity(float opacity)
        Set the opacity, in a complicated way. There are two things you need to know, how opacity is applied, and how opacity is implemented.

        First, GVRF does not sort by distance every object it can see, then draw from back to front. Rather, it sorts every object by render order, then draws the scene graph in traversal order. So, if you want to see a scene object through another scene object, you have to explicitly set the rendering order so that the translucent object draws after the opaque object. You can use any integer values you like, but GVRF supplies four standard values; the default value is GEOMETRY.

        Second, technically all this method does is set the opacity uniform. What this does depends on the actual shader. If you don't specify a shader (or you specify the unlit shader) setting opacity does exactly what you expect; you only have to worry about the render order. However, it is totally up to a custom shader whether or how it will handle opacity.

        Parameters:
        opacity - Value between 0.0f and 1.0f, inclusive.

      • setTexture

        public void setTexture(java.lang.String key,
                       GVRTexture texture)
        Description copied from interface: GVRShaders
        Bind a texture to the shader uniform key.

        Note that this will increment the reference count of the new texture, and decrement the reference count of any current texture. See GVRShaders.setMainTexture(GVRTexture) for more details.

        Specified by:
        setTexture in interface GVRShaders<GVRMaterialShaderId>
        Parameters:
        key - Name of the shader uniform to bind the texture to.
        texture - The texture to bind.
